awd_titl_txt: Cyanobacterial Cell Division: Mechanisms and Inputs Towards the Decision to Divide
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently, recognition of the considerable promise of cyanobacteria as engineering platforms for bioindustrial and sustainable bioenergy solutions has fueled growing interest in research on these organisms. This research project aims to address the molecular regulation of cyanobacterial cell division. The project will use a combination of biochemical methods, advanced microscopy, and computational simulation to investigate core mechanisms of cell division in cyanobacteria. The project will investigate the influence that light has on this organism's cell division. As a related part of the project, a new molecular biology approach designed to allow experimental control of the abundance of target proteins in cyanobacteria will be developed, providing an additional tool to study the important proteins controlling division, but also permitting a potentially powerful new method for cyanobacterial research and engineering. The fundamental knowledge to be gained from this project will be broadly relevant to scientific questions of evolution and ecology, as well as to cyanobacterial engineering and applications in "green" bioenergy. The proposal will also provide training opportunities for two graduate students and numerous undergraduates from underrepresented groups through undergraduate research experiences.

This project will employ the model unicellular rod-shaped cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongates, PCC7942, to investigate mechanistic and regulatory aspects of cell division in cyanobacteria. A combination of quantitative imaging, biochemical, molecular engineering, and modeling approaches will be used to understand how the unique cellular architecture and photosynthetic lifestyle of cyanobacteria impact their cell division systems in relation to those studied in classic heterotrophic models. Specifically, the S. elongatus homologs of the Min system proteins, which control the positioning of the cell division complex (divisome), will be investigated using localization studies involving careful construction of functional reporters expressed under endogenous and/or tunable promoters. The dynamics of the cyanobacterial Min proteins, their capacity to display oscillatory behavior, their genetic and biochemical interactions, and their influences on the organization of the divisome will be examined in relevant mutants and genetic backgrounds, and in the context of the large and potentially confounding thylakoid membrane system. The upstream influences of light, circadian rhythms, and photosynthetic metabolism on the control and activity of Min factors and cell division will also be investigated. To facilitate functional analysis of important/essential division proteins, a degron tag-based system will be developed to allow inducible degradation of target proteins. This technique may be broadly applicable to predictably regulating protein abundance beyond the scope of this project. Finally, the project will utilize computer simulations to examine the predicted effects of thylakoid membrane structure on the self-organization properties of the Min system and to compare modeling predictions to the experimentally derived results in S. elongatus.

por.por_cntn:
The growing "green economy" is largely dependent upon plants and plant-derived compounds that provide chemical building blocks (e.g., sugars) for the synthesis of valuable bioproducts (e.g., biofuels, bioplastics). Yet, there are practical problems related to growing enough crop plants to offset human demand for petrochemical compounds with bio-derived alternatives--succinctly referred to as the "food vs. fuel" dilemma. Cyanobacteria have been proposed as a potential solution, because they are photosynthetic microbes that can capture solar energy more efficiently than plants, and do not require potable water or arable farmlands to grow. In addition to their considerable biotechnological potential, cyanobacteria represent the ancestral, free-living cells that were the precursors of chloroplasts in plants and algae. Despite their importance, we lack a detailed understanding of some fundamental properties of how cyanobacteria grow, divide, and maintain their high photosynthetic efficiency. These processes are foundational for our fundamental understanding of cyanobacterial cell biology. They also have implications for plant biology, and for enabling these microbes to be grown at scale for biotechnology purposes.

Our research focus was on understanding how cyanobacteria partition cellular resources to daughter cells when they divide. Because of the requirements of photosynthetic metabolism, cyanobacteria have unusual physical characteristics. This includes the light-harvesting machinery that is contained within specialized membranes called thylakoid membranes, which are organized into a network that is much larger and more intricately structured than the membrane systems of non-photosynthetic bacteria. Similarly, the carbon fixation machinery in cyanobacteria is housed within subcellular protein compartments called carboxysomes. Cyanobacteria must, like other microbes, proportion their resources to both progeny when they divide, including provisioning their thylakoid membranes and carboxysomes equally. Our research investigated two core systems that cyanobacteria use as ?molecular yardsticks? to measure and divide the cell contents equally.

The first, called the Min system, is used by many bacteria to determine the physical middle point of the cell. In other bacteria, Min proteins act to regulate factors involved in cell division, and ensure that the machinery that coordinates cell constriction and fission assembles only at the cell center. However, the cyanobacterial Min system is different from that found in classically studied bacterial division models, containing a hybrid complement of Min genes from different bacteria. Furthermore, the thylakoid membranes present a physical barrier to the activity of Min proteins. Using a combination of genetic, molecular, and computational analyses we were able to show that the Min system is dynamic in cyanobacteria, oscillating back-and-forth from one end of the cell to the other as part of the mechanism that ensures division occurs only at the middle of the cell, and to make predictions as to how it circumnavigates the complex architecture of the thylakoid membranes. This information not only led to a new understanding of cyanobacterial cell biology, but also enabled us to rationally control the length of the cells in order to make them more favorable for bioindustrial applications. Specifically, we were able to modify cyanobacteria to make them harvestable by gravity and more easily broken open for recovery of internal bioproducts. Our scientific results therefore have implications for scaled-up cultivation of cyanobacteria as a crop species.

The second system we studied governs the positioning of carboxysomes within cyanobacteria. We elucidated the role of two critical proteins in controlling carboxysome positioning. One of these proteins is completely novel and had not been previously characterized in any microbial system. Nonetheless, we found that both proteins are present in a wide range of bacteria and therefore may have broad roles in controlling bacterial microcompartments in addition to carboxysomes. Our results also strongly support an alternative model for carboxysome distribution in cyanobacteria relative to what had been proposed previously in the field. Our findings suggest that no cytoskeletal network is necessary to organize and position carboxysomes, but that equidistant positioning of carboxysomes is driven as an emergent property from each carboxysome sensing a local chemical gradient within its cellular microenvironment. Beyond a role for controlling carboxysome partitioning equally upon cell division, our results strongly implicate this positional system in improving the efficiency of carbon capture in cyanobacteria, as mutants lacking this system are impaired in their growth. Finally, these results have implications for customizing microcompartments in bacteria to increase their utility for catalyzing other biochemical reactions, which is currently an emerging area of considerable potential in microbial bioengineering.  

Altogether, work associated with this Award resulted in the publication of four primary research articles, one review article, and the filing of one US patent. One doctoral student and one postdoctoral scholar were successfully trained under this award, and eight undergraduate students received rich research experiences.
